segments.pli: Aṅguttara Nikāya 7
segments.en: Numbered Discourses 7

segments.pli: 4. devatāvagga
segments.en: 4. Deities

segments.pli: 43. Dutiyaniddasasutta
segments.en: 43. Graduation (2nd)

segments.pli: Evaṃ me sutaṃ—
segments.en: So I have heard.

segments.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā kosambiyaṃ viharati ghositārāme.
segments.en: At one time the Buddha was staying near Kosambi, in Ghosita’s Monastery.

segments.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya kosambiṃ piṇḍāya pāvisi.
segments.en: Then Venerable Ānanda robed up in the morning and, taking his bowl and robe, entered Kosambi for alms.

segments.pli: Atha kho āyasmato ānandassa etadahosi:
segments.en: Then it occurred to him,

segments.pli: “atippago kho tāva kosambiyaṃ piṇḍāya carituṃ.
segments.en: “It’s too early to wander for alms in Kosambi.

segments.pli: Yannūnāhaṃ yena aññatitthiyānaṃ paribbājakānaṃ ārāmo tenupasaṅkameyyan”ti.
segments.en: Why don’t I go to the monastery of the wanderers who follow other paths?”

segments.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando yena aññatitthiyānaṃ paribbājakānaṃ ārāmo tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā tehi aññatitthiyehi paribbājakehi saddhiṃ sammodi.
segments.en: Then he went to the monastery of the wanderers who follow other paths, and exchanged greetings with the wanderers there.

segments.pli: Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi.
segments.en: When the greetings and polite conversation were over, he sat down to one side.

segments.pli: Tena kho pana samayena tesaṃ aññatitthiyānaṃ paribbājakānaṃ sannisinnānaṃ sannipatitānaṃ ayamantarākathā udapādi:
segments.en: Now at that time while those wanderers who follow other paths were sitting together this discussion came up among them,

segments.pli: “yo hi koci, āvuso, dvādasavassāni paripuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ carati, ‘niddaso bhikkhū’ti alaṃvacanāyā”ti.
segments.en: “Reverends, anyone who lives the full and pure spiritual life for twelve years is qualified to be called a ‘graduate mendicant’.”

segments.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando tesaṃ aññatitthiyānaṃ paribbājakānaṃ bhāsitaṃ neva abhinandi nappaṭikkosi.
segments.en: Ānanda neither approved nor dismissed that statement of the wanderers who follow other paths.

segments.pli: Anabhinanditvā appaṭikkositvā uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkāmi:
segments.en: He got up from his seat, thinking,

segments.pli: “bhagavato santike etassa bhāsitassa atthaṃ ājānissāmī”ti.
segments.en: “I will learn the meaning of this statement from the Buddha himself.”

segments.pli: Atha kho āyasmā ānando kosambiyaṃ piṇḍāya caritvā pacchābhattaṃ piṇḍapātapaṭikkanto yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ abhivādetvā ekamantaṃ nisīdi. Ekamantaṃ nisinno kho āyasmā ānando bhagavantaṃ etadavoca:
segments.en: Then Ānanda wandered for alms in Kosambi. After the meal, on his return from alms-round, he went to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what had happened, adding:

segments.pli: “Idhāhaṃ, bhante, pubbaṇhasamayaṃ nivāsetvā pattacīvaramādāya kosambiṃ piṇḍāya pāvisiṃ.
Tassa mayhaṃ, bhante, etadahosi:
‘atippago kho tāva kosambiyaṃ piṇḍāya carituṃ.
Yannūnāhaṃ yena aññatitthiyānaṃ paribbājakānaṃ ārāmo tenupasaṅkameyyan’ti … pe …
tehi saddhiṃ sammodiṃ.
Sammodanīyaṃ kathaṃ sāraṇīyaṃ vītisāretvā ekamantaṃ nisīdiṃ.
Tena kho pana, bhante, samayena tesaṃ aññatitthiyānaṃ paribbājakānaṃ sannisinnānaṃ sannipatitānaṃ ayamantarākathā udapādi:
‘yo hi koci, āvuso, dvādasavassāni paripuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ carati, niddaso bhikkhūti alaṃvacanāyā’ti.
Atha khvāhaṃ, bhante, tesaṃ aññatitthiyānaṃ paribbājakānaṃ bhāsitaṃ neva abhinandiṃ nappaṭikkosiṃ.
Anabhinanditvā, appaṭikkositvā uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkamiṃ:
‘bhagavato santike etassa bhāsitassa atthaṃ ājānissāmī’ti.
Sakkā nu kho, bhante, imasmiṃ dhammavinaye kevalaṃ vassagaṇanamattena niddaso bhikkhu paññāpetun”ti?
segments.en: “Sir, in this teaching and training can we describe a mendicant as a ‘graduate’ solely because they have completed a certain number of years?”

segments.pli: “Na kho, ānanda, sakkā imasmiṃ dhammavinaye kevalaṃ vassagaṇanamattena niddaso bhikkhu paññāpetuṃ.
segments.en: “No, Ānanda, we cannot.

segments.pli: Satta kho imāni, ānanda, niddasavatthūni mayā sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā paveditāni.
segments.en: These are the seven qualifications for graduation that I make known after realizing them with my own insight.

segments.pli: Katamāni satta?
segments.en: What seven?

segments.pli: Idhānanda, bhikkhu, saddho hoti, hirīmā hoti, ottappī hoti, bahussuto hoti, āraddhavīriyo hoti, satimā hoti, paññavā hoti.
segments.en: It’s when someone is faithful, conscientious, prudent, learned, energetic, mindful, and wise.

segments.pli: Imāni kho, ānanda, satta niddasavatthūni mayā sayaṃ abhiññā sacchikatvā paveditāni.
segments.en: These are the seven qualifications for graduation that I make known after realizing them with my own insight.

segments.pli: Imehi kho, ānanda, sattahi niddasavatthūhi samannāgato bhikkhu dvādasa cepi vassāni paripuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ carati, ‘niddaso bhikkhū’ti alaṃvacanāya;
segments.en: A mendicant who has these seven qualifications for graduation is qualified to be called a ‘graduate mendicant’. This is so whether they have lived the full and pure spiritual life for twelve years,

segments.pli: catubbīsati cepi vassāni paripuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ carati, ‘niddaso bhikkhū’ti alaṃvacanāya;
segments.en: twenty-four years,

segments.pli: chattiṃsati cepi vassāni paripuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ carati, ‘niddaso bhikkhū’ti alaṃvacanāya, aṭṭhacattārīsañcepi vassāni paripuṇṇaṃ parisuddhaṃ brahmacariyaṃ carati, ‘niddaso bhikkhū’ti alaṃvacanāyā”ti.
segments.en: thirty-six years, or forty-eight years.”

segments.pli: Dvādasamaṃ.
Devatāvaggo catuttho.
Appamādo hirī ceva,
dve suvacā duve mittā;
Dve paṭisambhidā dve vasā,
duve niddasavatthunāti.

suttaplex.blurb: Ānanda visits a sectarian hermitage and hears them saying that someone who lives the spiritual life for twelve years is fit to graduate. The Buddha rejects this, saying that a mendicant is qualified to graduate not merely by completing a certain number  of years, but because of their spiritual qualities.
